conclusion: High-level reasoning of shadow changes when light source moves backward and upward.
Rays become more parallel and come from a higher elevation angle when light source moves farther away.
Shadows move in the opposite direction to the light motion and become smaller.
Exact shadow shift or shrink depends on object's height and horizontal distance from light.
Taller objects produce larger positional shifts of their shadows.
Lower objects see a smaller change in shadow position and size.
All shadows (A, B, C, D) will migrate forward on the floor due to light moving backward.
All shadows will become smaller because the light is farther away and rays are closer to parallel.
If C's object is tallest, C's shadow shows the greatest forward shift and shrinkage.
If B is lowest, B's shadow shows the least forward shift and shrinkage.
Shadows A and D change by amounts in between, proportional to their objects' heights.
